data.text:
This title might be a small clickbait‚Ä¶but if you‚Äôre here, why not read the article anyway ü§∑ ?

If you directly want to test the final product: https://t.me/LNA_prediction_bot (I use some free hosting and free APIs, it can take up to 5min to wake up the bot when using it and it can also reach the limit of 500 API request/day)

Introduction

AI, ML, LLM have been in the mouth of every developer and digital enthusiast those last years. It‚Äôs surely a crazy time to live in and the idea of being able to breakthrough a lot of unsolved historical problems using those technologies is surely motivating. I always have a lot of interest for new technological stuff (it does certainly comes from my geeky side).

However, I also know by experience that a lot of those early interest that start as small side hobbies can quickly drop me in the dark side of the Mordor once I‚Äôve scratched the surface and try to understand more about the subject (like FPV drones, IOT or 3d printing‚Ä¶where debugging take more time and nights than the hobby itself‚Ä¶ Knows who knows).

This is why I want to say this now before you read more of this text: this article is by no mean a tutorial or a source of truth, it‚Äôs more an explanation of my curiosity journey toward the learning and development of my first ML project on the web as a Frontend and Creative engineer.

Feel free to enjoy the idea and development of the project by reading it while drinking a coffee. If you feel like you‚Äôre more in the mood of learning the technical side of this subject properly by someone who is more experienced, I invite you to read this article https://python.plainenglish.io/creating-machine-learning-models-to-predict-football-game-outcomes-70b6bf02885c or this one. Those are really good posts with detailed explanations.

The beginning

I have not a precise idea at where to start at this point. But one think I am pretty sure of, is that I‚Äôll need a basic dataset to start my project. For football (soccer) you‚Äôll find tones of nice dataset on Kaggle, but none for the Swiss hockey league. So let‚Äôs get to work and create or own starting dataset. This is something we can do by scrapping datas online using Selenium, puppeteer or some chrome extension for the more basic stuff like teams, location, dates or results. (We can go wayyyyy more complex here with the parameters, but let‚Äôs go slowly and scrap what we can easily, like: match date, scores, home and away team, ‚Ä¶).

‚ú®Magic happen‚ú®

Wooo, after this step we have all the match from 1856BC to 2024. Now what else ?

Using just the basic informations of the match would not bring a lot and also I don‚Äôt think that results from to far in the past would give us any useful datas for our predictions. So let‚Äôs firstly remove all match that happened before 2008.

What other data could be useful ?

After reading some articles online I quickly understood the complexity of building a good and accurate dataset (creating a good one will take weeks/months and a lot of testing‚Ä¶), as said, I am by no mean experienced in ML and don‚Äôt want to spend 1 year on the dataset only‚Ä¶, so as first project I wanted to keep my focus on an easy solution to learn the basics, but I still wanted a solution that could lead me to get some nice results.

This is when I fumbled on this really good video from Crypto Wizards :

The idea is to use the historical datas from bookies and the real match results as a key value points for predictions and try to beat the brookies on the bet. This idea looked pretty interesting for me as I can find those data online and I don‚Äôt need to start listing and cross merging complex data in my dataset (team players, referee, ‚Ä¶). So let‚Äôs get those datas and add them in our dataset. Here some parts of the python code used during the process:

# Load the datas from our 2csv for merging

df1 = pd.read_csv('saison_2008_2020.csv', delimiter=';')

df2 = pd.read_csv('Odds_2008_2020.csv')

# Define the mapping function to standardize team names as it comes from different sources

def standardize_team_names(team_name):

mapping = {

'HC Ambri-Piotta': 'Ambri-Piotta',

'EV Zug': 'Zug',

'Fribourg-Gott√©ron': 'Fribourg',

'SCL Tigers': 'Langnau Tigers',

'SC Bern': 'Bern',

'Lausanne HC': 'Lausanne',

'EHC Biel-Bienne': 'Biel',

'ZSC Lions': 'Zurich',

'HC Lugano': 'Lugano',

'Gen√®ve-Servette HC': 'Servette',

'SC Rapperswil-Jona Lakers': 'Rapperswil',

'HC Davos': 'Davos',

'HC Ajoie': 'Ajoie',

'HC La Chaux-de-Fonds':'La Chaux-de-Fonds'

}

return mapping.get(team_name, team_name) # Return original if not in mapping

# Since File 1 might not be in datetime format, we adjust this line to ensure it is

df1['Datum'] = pd.to_datetime(df1['Datum'], format='%d.%m.%y')

# Merge the datasets on 'Datum', 'Home' ('TeamA' in File 2), and 'Away' ('TeamB' in File 2)

merged_data = pd.merge(df1, df2, left_on=['Datum', 'Home', 'Away'], right_on=['Datum', 'TeamA', 'TeamB'], how='left')

# Remove rows with missing data in any of the odds columns

original_count = len(df)

df.dropna(subset=cont_vars, inplace=True)

removed_count = original_count - len(df)

print(f"\nRemoved {removed_count} rows with missing odds data.")

I will use this basic dataset for this project, as said we could go way more complex if we wanted to improve our precision. But as learned from an episode in this lesson it‚Äôs always good to create a first model as soon as possible before to spend to much time on the improvement of the dataset :)

Let‚Äôs start with the training.

BTW, I made this dataset open sourceon Kaggle here if some of my fellow Swiss coders or hockey fans want to use it or improve it.

Training our model with fastai

In this section, we‚Äôll dive into the process of training our machine learning model using Fastai, a popular deep learning library built on top of PyTorch. Fastai provides a high-level API that simplifies the process of training neural networks, which is what we need right now :)

We do have our data ready, so let‚Äôs train a model:

# Define preprocessing steps

procs = [Categorify, FillMissing, Normalize]

# Define categorical and continuous columns again if needed

cat_vars = ['Home', 'Away']

cont_vars = ['OddsTeamA', 'OddsTeamB', 'OddsX']

# Define splits for training and validation

splits = RandomSplitter(valid_pct=0.2)(df)

# Prepare your TabularPandas object, ensuring all arguments are correctly utilized

to = TabularPandas(df, procs=procs, cat_names=cat_vars, cont_names=cont_vars,

y_names='Winner', splits=splits)

# Print the first few rows of the processed training set to inspect

print("Processed training set preview:")

print(to.train.xs.head())

# Create DataLoaders

dls = to.dataloaders(bs=64)

learn = tabular_learner(dls, layers=[200, 100], metrics=[accuracy, Precision()])

# Find the optimal learning rate

learn.lr_find()

# Train the model using the fit_one_cycle method

learn.fit_one_cycle(5, 1e-2)

# Show results to evaluate the model

learn.show_results()

It‚Äôs a pretty basic model yes, but as a first I am happy with that for now.

Using psychology and UX/UI to create an addictive gambling app‚Ä¶

Kidding, I will create a Telegram bot‚Ä¶ because it‚Äôs easier and less time consuming for a side project. Here is a basic idea of the project structure:

We can split this futur project like that: Our client (Telegram app), our telegram Python bot script, external API that return the futur matchs/odds and our ML Python endpoint that return the estimation of the result.

Preparing our Python APIs using Flask

Having a working project locally is always nice. But my goal is to be able to integrate my ML as an API. This way I‚Äôll be able to use it everywhere in the future and I‚Äôll be able to call it from my Telegram bot script ü§ñ

Let‚Äôs create that. I wanted to keep all my work on Python and avoid any unnecessary code migration. This is why I decided to use Flask for Python in order to create my API endpoint.

Using our fastai model anywhere

We trained our fastai model and we want to be able to use it in our API. In order to do that we can serialize it using the command:

learn.export('model_v1.pkl')

This will create a pickle file (.PKL) that we can later load in our code in order to use the trained model.

#Loading and using the exported model

learn = load_learner('model_v1.pkl')

#...

# Convert the incoming data to a DataFrame

new_data = pd.DataFrame({

'Home': [Home],

'Away': [Away],

'OddsTeamA': [OddsTeamA],

'OddsTeamB': [OddsTeamB],

'OddsX': [OddsX]

})

dl = learn.dls.test_dl(new_data)

#Here we get the predictions

preds, _ = learn.get_preds(dl=dl)

prediction = preds[0].tolist()

Now, if we integrate this in our /predict route created with Flask

@app.route(‚Äò/predict‚Äô, methods=[‚ÄòPOST‚Äô]) we get an endpoint that we can call from anywhere by passing to it the parameters we defined:

Hosting

As a big user of Vercel for all my Frontend deployment I wanted to see if I was able to use it to host my Python API. The answer is ‚Äúyes you can‚Ä¶but it‚Äôs not the easiest way right now in my opinion‚Äù. I was able to make it work but faced some weird issues when using Vercel cli locally to run their Python runtime (still Beta as I write this article so let‚Äôs wait for the future).

In the end I decided to use gunicorn with Flask. I hosted my ML api code on render.com and I hosted the telegram bot on a Jetlastic instance (hosted by Infomaniak).

I found it way easier and less restrictive in my workflow, the prices of the services are also ok in my opinion if we need an upgrade in the future.

A bit of betting logic for our Bot

Giving back the probability of win to the end user is cool. But when it comes to betting, simply knowing the probability of a win isn‚Äôt enough to make an good decision. While having an accurate win probability is crucial, it‚Äôs not the only factor one should consider before placing a bet.

Equally important are the odds offered by bookmakers. If these odds are less favorable than the implied probability of the win then we can say that the bet might not be worth the risk.

Example

Win Probability: This is the chance that a particular outcome will occur given our ML API response. For instance, if a team has a 70% chance of winning a game, the win probability returned is 0.7

Odds: These are the bookmakers‚Äô way of expressing the likelihood of an outcome and determining payouts. For example, odds of 1.2 mean that for every 1$ you bet, you would win 1.20$ if the bet is successful.

To decide whether a bet is worth placing, you need to compare the implied probability derived from the odds with your own estimated win probability. So we can say that:

OddsWorthBettingFrom=1/Probability

For example if the win probability given by our ML is 62% we can say that a bet is worth placing if the odds given by the brooker are higher than 1/0.62=1.61

Now that we understand this, we can use our code to determine if a bet is worth the risk, we can provide a useful information to the end user, telling him which odds are worth betting on or not, instead of just sending back a win probability.

#we calculate the implied probability

oddsOkFrom = round(1 / ml_probability, 2)

#We return a better response

response = (

f"üèÜ {winning_team} have {ml_probability * 100:.1f}% chance to win this game.\n"

f"‚úÖ It's worth betting on {winning_team} if odds of the booker are higher than {oddsOkFrom}\n"

)

With this done, we now will receive all the informations for the next match.

Our Telegram Bot

The telegram bot commands are straight forward in this V1 with just one command that we define:

/next_match ‚Üí will provide the next match or a list of the next matchs happening at the same time and the expected outcome for each match.

Main part of the bot code is this function that will call the different API and manage the matchs return:

# Async function to handle the 'next_match' command

async def next_match(update: Update, context: ContextTypes.DEFAULT_TYPE):

#...

# Make the request to the API

response = requests.get(url, headers=headers, params=payload)

matches = response.json()

ns_matches = [match for match in matches['response'] if match['status']['short'] == 'NS']

if ns_matches:

# Get the earliest match time

earliest_match_time = min(ns_matches, key=lambda x: x['timestamp'])['timestamp']

# Get all matches that happen at the earliest match time

earliest_matches = [match for match in ns_matches if match['timestamp'] == earliest_match_time]

for match in earliest_matches:

# Extract relevant match information

home_team = match['teams']['home']['name']

away_team = match['teams']['away']['name']

match_date = match['date']

# Convert the match date to a readable format

date_object = datetime.fromisoformat(match_date)

formatted_date = date_object.strftime("%d %B %Y at %H:%M")

#....

Conclusion

This project is by no means a final product that one could rely on. In fact, I am pretty sure you will achieve better results by trusting your instincts rather than depending on my model, it also tends to always make an away team favorite for now‚Ä¶

The good news is that with the current structure of the code, I can from now on easily focus 100% on training a model to enhance accuracy without modifying a single line of the project‚Äôs core code.

It was a fun and educational experiment that allowed me to explore new possibilities, learn the very basics of machine learning, and gain insights into the current capabilities of web-based ML APIs. Additionally, it was my first experience integrating a Telegram bot into such a project. I believe this approach could be useful for specific use cases in the future, offering a fast and convenient way to fetch basic data without the need to develop a frontend.
